abstractText: To assess the expected accuracy of genetic stock identification with a given baseline data set, geneticists working on Pacific salmon typically run two types of tests using genetic software.  The first test is 100% simulations which involve repeatedly simulating mixtures by resampling from the baseline, simulating new baselines by resampling from the baseline, and analyzing the simulated mixtures with the simulated baselines. A second test, called leave-one-out (LOO) involves removing each individual from the baseline (one at a time) and and estimating their population (or reporting group) of origin using the method of Rannala and Mountain (1997).
title: Predicting the accuracy of genetic stock identification v1.0
